title: Overseas Chinese Affairs Office sends traditional Chinese physicians to Indonesia in April 2007
description: On April 10, 2007, a team of 7 traditional Chinese medical experts arrived in Jakarta for their 16-day free medical consultation tour around Indonesia. This project was financed by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Overseas Chinese Affairs Office sends traditional Chinese physicians to Indonesia in April 2007

# Description
On April 10, 2007, a team of 7 traditional Chinese medical experts arrived in Jakarta for their 16-day free medical consultation tour around Indonesia. This project was financed by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Traditional Chinese medical experts providing free medical consultation, healthcare focus

title: China donates USD 2.13 million of medical equipment through WHO for post-tsunami relief efforts
description: On January 31, 2007, the Chinese government donated medical supplies to the Indonesian Ministry of Health through the World Health Organization (WHO) in response to the 2004 tsunami. A total of USD 2.13 million of aid materials, including 15 ambulances, 10 cooling containers for blood preservation and 10 operating suits, as well as X-ray, ultrasonography and electrocardiogram units will be donated to Aceh Hospital and Medical Center.   According to the ministry's Crisis Mitigation Center head, Rustam S. Pakaya, some of the aid has already been distributed to Aceh and Nias.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates USD 2.13 million of medical equipment through WHO for post-tsunami relief efforts

# Description
On January 31, 2007, the Chinese government donated medical supplies to the Indonesian Ministry of Health through the World Health Organization (WHO) in response to the 2004 tsunami. A total of USD 2.13 million of aid materials, including 15 ambulances, 10 cooling containers for blood preservation and 10 operating suits, as well as X-ray, ultrasonography and electrocardiogram units will be donated to Aceh Hospital and Medical Center.   According to the ministry's Crisis Mitigation Center head, Rustam S. Pakaya, some of the aid has already been distributed to Aceh and Nias.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and medical equipment donation, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Medical supplies donation, ambulances, medical equipment for hospital use, post-tsunami relief efforts

title: China Development Bank supports China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd.'s issuing of $140 million supplier credit for 200MW Jeneponto Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project
description: In 2007, China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd. — a Chinese state-owned company — and PT Bosowa Energi (Bosowa Corporation) signed a $140 million supplier credit (loan) agreement for the 200MW Jeneponto Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project. This loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 7-year maturity and a 6% annual interest rate.  China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd., in turn, secured a loan (most likely an export seller’s credit) with a 10-year maturity from China Development Bank (CDB) in order to finance the supplier credit. Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI) also issued a $60 million loan in support of the $200 million project.   The purpose of the project was to install a 200-megawatt (MW) coal-fired power plant — with two 100MW generators (Unit 1 and Unit 2) — in Punagayya Village, Bangkala District, Jeneponto Regency, and South Sulawesi Province (exact locational coordinates: -5.6180, 119.5488). China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd. was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. On August 19, 2007, a formal groundbreaking ceremony was held. The power plant was initially planned to be completed in 2009. However, the project was temporarily halted when CDB suspended loan disbursements pending the outcome of another project. The plant was officially inaugurated on December 19, 2012.  Chinese Ambassador to Indonesia, Liu Jian Chao, attended the inauguration ceremony and said that ‘This project was built on a cooperation agreement between the Chinese government and the Indonesian government. We are committed to continuing to assist infrastructure development in this country.’
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Jeneponto 2x100MW Coal-Fired Power Station Project or the PLTU Punagaya Jeneponto 2x125 MW Project. The Indonesian project title is Proyek PLTU Jeneponto. The Chinese project title is 的印尼杰纳旁托燃煤电站项目. PT Bosowa Energi (Bosowa Corporation) is a private Indonesian company.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Development Bank supports China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd.'s issuing of $140 million supplier credit for 200MW Jeneponto Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project

# Description
In 2007, China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd. — a Chinese state-owned company — and PT Bosowa Energi (Bosowa Corporation) signed a $140 million supplier credit (loan) agreement for the 200MW Jeneponto Coal-Fired Power Plant Construction Project. This loan carried the following borrowing terms: a 7-year maturity and a 6% annual interest rate.  China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd., in turn, secured a loan (most likely an export seller’s credit) with a 10-year maturity from China Development Bank (CDB) in order to finance the supplier credit. Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BRI) also issued a $60 million loan in support of the $200 million project.   The purpose of the project was to install a 200-megawatt (MW) coal-fired power plant — with two 100MW generators (Unit 1 and Unit 2) — in Punagayya Village, Bangkala District, Jeneponto Regency, and South Sulawesi Province (exact locational coordinates: -5.6180, 119.5488). China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd. was the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. On August 19, 2007, a formal groundbreaking ceremony was held. The power plant was initially planned to be completed in 2009. However, the project was temporarily halted when CDB suspended loan disbursements pending the outcome of another project. The plant was officially inaugurated on December 19, 2012.  Chinese Ambassador to Indonesia, Liu Jian Chao, attended the inauguration ceremony and said that ‘This project was built on a cooperation agreement between the Chinese government and the Indonesian government. We are committed to continuing to assist infrastructure development in this country.’
justification: Primary purpose is construction of a coal-fired power plant, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: 200MW coal-fired power plant with two 100MW generators, coal as primary fuel source

title: Chinese Government supported Phase I of Natural Medicinal Plant Research and Development Project (linked to #37904)
description: In 2007, the Chinese Government provided financial assistance to the first phase of the Research and Development of Natural Medicinal Plants Project in Indonesia. The project involves collecting Indonesian medicinal plant resources and training Indonesian science and technology personnel. On December 3, 2009, the signing of the memorandum of understanding for the second phase of the project marked the completion of the first phase. The exact start date and grant amount are unclear.   According to the Baidu page for Fu Chengxin, a plant geneticist and professor at Zhejiang University's School of Life Sciences, he was involved with the project which took place on March 31, 2007.   It is linked to #37904, the grant from Chinese government for the second phase of the project.

justification: Project focuses on research and development of medicinal plants and personnel training, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Research and development of natural medicinal plants, training of science and technology personnel, healthcare sector focus

title: China granted RMB 36.3m for Consultancy Study Reports on Technical Revitalization of Indonesian Strategic Industries
description: In July 2007, China provided a grant of RMB 36.3 million (approximately USD 5.3 million)  to provide consulting for the construction of Indonesia's defense industry system and the technological revitalization of the four strategic enterprises: Dirgantara Aviation Plant, PINDAD Arsenal, PAL Shipyard, and Krakatau Steel Plant. China New Era Holdings Group and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Indonesia signed the "Technical Reform Consulting Project Contract for Strategic Enterprises in Indonesia" to implement the project.   On July 14, 2009, the handover ceremony for the technical transformation consulting project took place, marking the completion of the project. ("中国政府援印尼四大战略企业技改咨询项目顺利交接")

China New Era Holdings Group and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Indonesia signed the "Technical Reform Consulting Project Contract for Strategic Enterprises in Indonesia" to implement the project.   On July 14, 2009, the handover ceremony for the technical transformation consulting project took place, marking the completion of the project. title: Hanban provides grant for the establishment of Confucius Institute at Jakarta BTIP
description: On September 28, 2007, the Jakarta BTIP Confucius (or Kongzi) Institute in Indonesia was inaugurated. It is co-founded by Hainan Normal University (HNU) and Bina Terampil Insan Persada (BTIP or Skilled Development of Persada Individuals) under the authorization of the Office of Chinese Language Council International-- also called Hanban. It is the first of its kind in Indonesia. The cost of the project is unknown, but the Chinese government predominantly finances Confucius Institutes through grants.  The Jakarta BTIP Confucius Institute's primary task will be to teach Chinese language skills but also to share Chinese culture and art.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban provides grant for the establishment of Confucius Institute at Jakarta BTIP

# Description
On September 28, 2007, the Jakarta BTIP Confucius (or Kongzi) Institute in Indonesia was inaugurated. It is co-founded by Hainan Normal University (HNU) and Bina Terampil Insan Persada (BTIP or Skilled Development of Persada Individuals) under the authorization of the Office of Chinese Language Council International-- also called Hanban. It is the first of its kind in Indonesia. The cost of the project is unknown, but the Chinese government predominantly finances Confucius Institutes through grants.  The Jakarta BTIP Confucius Institute's primary task will be to teach Chinese language skills but also to share Chinese culture and art.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for Chinese language teaching and cultural sharing

title: China Eximbank provides loan for Bengkulu Coal Mine Project
description: In 2007, China Eximbank‘s Jiangxi Provincial branch issued a loan to Zhongding International Engineering Co. Ltd for the Bengkulu Coal Mine Project. The face value and the borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The purpose of the project was to develop an underground coal mine in Bengkulu Province on the island of Sumatra  (朋古鲁煤矿). Construction of the first well began in October 2007. Construction of the second well began in May 2009. Upon completion, the mine was expected to produce 1.2 million tons of coal a year. On March 31, 2018, the project was officially completed and handed over to its local owner. China Eximbank conducted an on-site, post-loan project inspection on May 26, 2018.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 印尼朋古鲁煤矿 or 朋古鲁煤矿位 or 印尼朋古鲁煤矿投资合作开采项目 or 中鼎国际印尼朋古鲁煤矿二井及自备电厂项目. 2. Intent of project marked as mixed as loan provided was likely an overseas investment loan to support Zhongding's investment in constructing the coal mine.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides loan for Bengkulu Coal Mine Project

# Description
In 2007, China Eximbank‘s Jiangxi Provincial branch issued a loan to Zhongding International Engineering Co. Ltd for the Bengkulu Coal Mine Project. The face value and the borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. The purpose of the project was to develop an underground coal mine in Bengkulu Province on the island of Sumatra  (朋古鲁煤矿). Construction of the first well began in October 2007. Construction of the second well began in May 2009. Upon completion, the mine was expected to produce 1.2 million tons of coal a year. On March 31, 2018, the project was officially completed and handed over to its local owner. China Eximbank conducted an on-site, post-loan project inspection on May 26, 2018.
justification: Project is focused on coal mining, which is environmentally harmful and inhibits energy transition
evidence: Development of underground coal mine, expected production of 1.2 million tons of coal annually

title: Bank of China contributes to a $884 million USD syndicated loan for Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project (Linked to Project ID#97811)
description: On October 29, 2007, a syndicate of banks (including Bank of China, BTMU, DNB, Intesa San Paulo, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd., and Royal Bank of Scotland) signed an $884 million loan agreement with a trustee [HSBC USA (New York)] and Japan International Finance Management (Tangguh) Corporation — a special purpose vehicle (SPV) — for the Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Project. The loan carried a maturity of 13.6 years and an interest rate of LIBOR (October 2007 6M LIBOR: 5.051%) plus a 0.335% margin. China National Offshore Oil Corporation  (CNOOC) — a Chinese state-owned enterprise — issued a corporate guarantee in support of the loan. Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd., served as the facility agent for the loan.   The $884 million loan, known as the ‘Fujian tranche,’ is ring-fenced from the rest of the project and the revenues to service it will be drawn from the 25-year contract to supply 2.6 million tonnes per annum (mtpa) of LNG to CNOOC, initially through the latter’s Fujian LNG-receiving terminal. Under the trustee borrowing structure, loans are repaid from an agreed portion of gross proceeds under identified offtake contracts. The buyers make payments directly to the trustee and paying agent [HSBC USA (New York)]. The trustee is also the borrower under the loan agreement with the lenders, and the debt service payments are made from the trustee accounts. Except as otherwise provided, the lenders look to this source of debt service for all loans, with no recourse to the project and no security interest in the project assets or contracts.   Prior to the issuance of this loan, several other loans were issued for the same project: a $1.2 billion loan from Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), a $350 million loan from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), a $1.066 billion syndicated loan from a group of commercial banks, and an August 2006 $1.3 billion USD syndicated term loan from a syndicate of five Chinese state-owned banks — Agricultural Bank of China (ABC), China Construction Bank Corporation (CCB), China Development Bank (CB), the Export-Import Bank of China, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) — as captured via Project ID#97811.  The debt financing package involves a complex multi-tranche Indonesian trustee borrowing structure. Repayment of the loans is supported by revenues from long-term LNG sale and purchase agreements with K-Power in South Korea, POSCO in South Korea and Sempra Energy via a receiving terminal in Mexico.   The purpose of the project is to construct an integrated greenfield liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility — with two LNG process trains (Train 1 and 2) — on the south side of Bintuni Bay in Teluk Bintuni Regency within Papua Barat Province. The LNG plant is comprised of two main components: (i) the offshore gas production facilities including 14 producing wells, 2 platforms (“trains”), and subsea pipelines to feed gas to the onshore facilities; and (ii) the onshore LNG production facilities and associated facilities, which include two identical production trains (Train 1 and 2), storage tanks for LNG (2 x 170,000 m3 ) and condensate (1 x 120,000 barrel), marine berthing facilities, utilities, offices and living facilities, off-site camp, airfield and jetty. Design optimizations together with deferral of the airfield and associated access road almost halved the site footprint. Upon completion, it was envisaged that the project would have 7.6 million tons per annum (mtpa) of production capacity to the existing Tangguh LNG facility.   The Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project took shape in the mid-1990s upon the discovery of substantial gas reserves in the area. Proven reserves are around 14.4 trillion cubic feet (TCF). The project was initiated in 1997 by Atlantic Richfield Company (a US oil company) and Pertamina (a state-owned oil and gas enterprise). In April 1999, BP Plc (BP) acquired Atlantic Richfield Company and took over its lead role. Its 7 gas fields, under production-sharing contracts (PSCs), are developed under a partnership between consortia of international contractors (the PSC Contractors) and BPMIGAS as the governmental counterparty. The PSC Contractors, led by BP Berau as the Operator, operate jointly in upstream development and LNG processing for export to international markets. In May 2003, BP approached multilateral and bilateral financial institutions to seek financial assistance together with a commitment to assist the project in implementing best practices following international environmental and social guidelines.    The project began construction following the resettlement in July 2004 of Tanah Merah village (the LNG plant site). Engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contracts were entered into with a consortium of Kellogg Overseas Corporation, JGC, and PT Pertafenikki (KJP; for onshore facilities) and with PT Saipem Indonesia (for offshore facilities) in March 2005, followed by immediate issuance of the notice to proceed to start the construction. As of March 2007, the project had achieved a 70% completion rate. The offshore facilities were handed over to the project owner by May 2007. The onshore facilities were ready for start-up in January 2009 (Train 1) and June (Train 2) 2009. The first LNG production (first drop) occurred in Train 1 in June 2009. The first LNG shipment was made on July 6, 2009 using the Tangguh Foja LNG carrier.  Following the project’s achievement of ready for start-up status in 2009, the start-up process continued until mid-2011 to address technical issues, perform modification works, and ensure the stable operation and higher production efficiency of the LNG plant. Over a 3-year period from first drop in June 2009 up to June 2012 the project had produced a total of 37.8 million m3 of LNG and 5.1 million barrels of condensate.   Bank of China also contributed to a syndicated loan in 2016 that financed the third train of the Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project (captured in Project ID#73318).
staff_comments: 1. The individual contribution of Bank of China to the syndicated loan is unknown. For the time being, AidData has estimated the contribution ($650,217,295) of Bank of China by assuming that the six lenders contributed equal amounts ($147,333,333.33) to the $884 million loan syndicate.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Bank of China contributes to a $884 million USD syndicated loan for Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project (Linked to Project ID#97811)

# Description
On October 29, 2007, a syndicate of banks (including Bank of China, BTMU, DNB, Intesa San Paulo, Mizuho Corporate Bank, Ltd., and Royal Bank of Scotland) signed an $884 million loan agreement with a trustee [HSBC USA (New York)] and Japan International Finance Management (Tangguh) Corporation — a special purpose vehicle (SPV) — for the Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) Project. The buyers make payments directly to the trustee and paying agent [HSBC USA (New York)]. The trustee is also the borrower under the loan agreement with the lenders, and the debt service payments are made from the trustee accounts. Except as otherwise provided, the lenders look to this source of debt service for all loans, with no recourse to the project and no security interest in the project assets or contracts.   Prior to the issuance of this loan, several other loans were issued for the same project: a $1.2 billion loan from Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), a $350 million loan from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), a $1.066 billion syndicated loan from a group of commercial banks, and an August 2006 $1.3 billion USD syndicated term loan from a syndicate of five Chinese state-owned banks — Agricultural Bank of China (ABC), China Construction Bank Corporation (CCB), China Development Bank (CB), the Export-Import Bank of China, and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) — as captured via Project ID#97811. Repayment of the loans is supported by revenues from long-term LNG sale and purchase agreements with K-Power in South Korea, POSCO in South Korea and Sempra Energy via a receiving terminal in Mexico. Upon completion, it was envisaged that the project would have 7.6 million tons per annum (mtpa) of production capacity to the existing Tangguh LNG facility.   The Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project took shape in the mid-1990s upon the discovery of substantial gas reserves in the area. Proven reserves are around 14.4 trillion cubic feet (TCF). The project was initiated in 1997 by Atlantic Richfield Company (a US oil company) and Pertamina (a state-owned oil and gas enterprise). In April 1999, BP Plc (BP) acquired Atlantic Richfield Company and took over its lead role. Its 7 gas fields, under production-sharing contracts (PSCs), are developed under a partnership between consortia of international contractors (the PSC Contractors) and BPMIGAS as the governmental counterparty. The PSC Contractors, led by BP Berau as the Operator, operate jointly in upstream development and LNG processing for export to international markets. In May 2003, BP approached multilateral and bilateral financial institutions to seek financial assistance together with a commitment to assist the project in implementing best practices following international environmental and social guidelines.    The project began construction following the resettlement in July 2004 of Tanah Merah village (the LNG plant site). Engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contracts were entered into with a consortium of Kellogg Overseas Corporation, JGC, and PT Pertafenikki (KJP; for onshore facilities) and with PT Saipem Indonesia (for offshore facilities) in March 2005, followed by immediate issuance of the notice to proceed to start the construction. As of March 2007, the project had achieved a 70% completion rate. The offshore facilities were handed over to the project owner by May 2007. The onshore facilities were ready for start-up in January 2009 (Train 1) and June (Train 2) 2009. The first LNG production (first drop) occurred in Train 1 in June 2009. The first LNG shipment was made on July 6, 2009 using the Tangguh Foja LNG carrier.  Following the project’s achievement of ready for start-up status in 2009, the start-up process continued until mid-2011 to address technical issues, perform modification works, and ensure the stable operation and higher production efficiency of the LNG plant. Over a 3-year period from first drop in June 2009 up to June 2012 the project had produced a total of 37.8 million m3 of LNG and 5.1 million barrels of condensate.   Bank of China also contributed to a syndicated loan in 2016 that financed the third train of the Tangguh Liquefied Natural Gas Project (captured in Project ID#73318).
justification: Primary purpose is development of LNG infrastructure, which is a fossil fuel project
evidence: Construction of integrated LNG facility with offshore gas production and onshore LNG processing, long-term LNG supply contracts, and significant fossil fuel reserves

title: Bank of China Trust contributes $60 million USD to a $120 million USD syndicated loan to PT Federal International Finance for motorcycle financing
description: In August 2007, Bank of China Trust (an arm of BOC) participated in a $120 million USD syndicated loan to PT Federal international Finance (FIF), a unit of PT Astra Internasional Tbk. Bank of China Trust and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation were the arrangers and each arranged 50% of the financing ($60 million USD). This loan carried a maturity period of three years and an interest rate less than Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) plus 1%. The loan was oversubscribed from $75 million USD. The proceeds were to be used to support motorcycle financing of FIF.
combined_text:
# Sector
BUSINESS AND OTHER SERVICES

# Title
Bank of China Trust contributes $60 million USD to a $120 million USD syndicated loan to PT Federal International Finance for motorcycle financing

# Description
In August 2007, Bank of China Trust (an arm of BOC) participated in a $120 million USD syndicated loan to PT Federal international Finance (FIF), a unit of PT Astra Internasional Tbk. Bank of China Trust and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation were the arrangers and each arranged 50% of the financing ($60 million USD). This loan carried a maturity period of three years and an interest rate less than Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) plus 1%. The loan was oversubscribed from $75 million USD. The proceeds were to be used to support motorcycle financing of FIF.
justification: Project involves financial services for motorcycle financing without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Syndicated loan for motorcycle financing, no direct energy or environmental components

title: ICBC (Asia) contributes to USD 200 million syndicated loan to Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings (APRIL) for unspecified purposes
description: In November 2007, a group of five banks -- including ICBC (Asia) -- signed an agreement to provide a USD 200 million syndicated loan to Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings (APRIL), part of Royal Golden Eagle Group, which is an international conglomerate with common beneficial owners in Indonesia's Sukanto Tanoto and members of his family. The facility has a maturity of 3.125 years, a grace period of 15 months, and carries a maturity of LIBOR plus 300 basis points. The loan was oversubscribed during syndication. As of November 23, 2007, the borrower was considering whether to exercise a USD 100 million greenshoe option (to increase the loan to USD 300 million), but it is unclear whether it did so. Proceeds are for unspecified purposes.  Credit Suisse served as mandated lead arranger and bookrunner, with the other four banks: ICBC (Asia), Fortis Bank, Standard Bank, and WestLB joining equal-status arrangers.
staff_comments: 1. AidData is unable to ascertain individual contributions made to the facility by each member of the syndicate, therefore equal contributions from each lender have been assumed (200/5).2. AidData has calculated the interest rate for this loan using the six-month LIBOR rate from November 2007 (4.832%). For more information, see: https://www.global-rates.com/en/interest-rates/libor/american-dollar/2007.aspx
combined_text:
# Sector
UNALLOCATED/UNSPECIFIED

# Title
ICBC (Asia) contributes to USD 200 million syndicated loan to Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings (APRIL) for unspecified purposes

# Description
In November 2007, a group of five banks -- including ICBC (Asia) -- signed an agreement to provide a USD 200 million syndicated loan to Asia Pacific Resources International Holdings (APRIL), part of Royal Golden Eagle Group, which is an international conglomerate with common beneficial owners in Indonesia's Sukanto Tanoto and members of his family. The facility has a maturity of 3.125 years, a grace period of 15 months, and carries a maturity of LIBOR plus 300 basis points. The loan was oversubscribed during syndication. As of November 23, 2007, the borrower was considering whether to exercise a USD 100 million greenshoe option (to increase the loan to USD 300 million), but it is unclear whether it did so. Proceeds are for unspecified purposes.  Credit Suisse served as mandated lead arranger and bookrunner, with the other four banks: ICBC (Asia), Fortis Bank, Standard Bank, and WestLB joining equal-status arrangers.
justification: Loan for unspecified purposes to a conglomerate with diverse business interests, no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Unspecified loan purposes, financial services nature of transaction
